statements.name: PROC IMPORT
statements.description: Imports an external data file to a SAS data set or table .

arguments.name: DATAFILE=
arguments.description: specifies the complete path and filename or fileref for the input PC file, spreadsheet, or delimited external file. A fileref is a SAS name that is associated with the physical location of the output file. To assign a fileref, use the FILENAME statement. For more information about the FILENAME statement, see . For more information about PC file formats, see

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: identifies the output SAS data set with either a one or two-level SAS name (library and member name). If the specified SAS data set does not exist, the IMPORT procedure creates it. If you specify a one-level name, by default the IMPORT procedure uses either the USER library (if assigned) or the WORK library (if USER is not assigned). The physical data set name is created using upper-case letters. In SAS programs running on case-sensitive operating systems, this data set name might need to be referenced with upper-case letters.

arguments.name: TABLE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the input DBMS table. If the name does not include special characters (such as question marks), lowercase characters, or spaces, you can omit the quotation marks. Note that the DBMS table name might be case sensitive.

arguments.name: DBMS=
arguments.description: specifies the type of data to import.

arguments.name: CSV
arguments.description: The output data source is a comma-separated delimited file. The file extension is .CSV.

arguments.name: DLM
arguments.description: The output data source is a delimited file. You can use DELIMITER='char' to specifiy the type of data to export.

arguments.name: DTA
arguments.description: The output data source is a Stata file. The file extension is .dta.

arguments.name: JMP
arguments.description: The output data source is a JMP file, Version 7 or later format. The file extension is .JMP.

arguments.name: PARADOX
arguments.description: The output data source is a Paradox DB file. The file extension is .db.

arguments.name: SAV
arguments.description: The output data source is a SPSS file. The file extension is .sav.

arguments.name: TAB
arguments.description: The output data source is a tab delimited file. The file extension is .txt.

arguments.name: XLS
arguments.description: Microsoft Excel 97, 2000, 2002, or 2003 spreadsheet using file formats. The file extension is .xls.

arguments.name: XLSX
arguments.description: Excel 2007, 2010, and later spreadsheet, using .xlsx file format. The file extension is .xlsx.

arguments.name: Microsoft
arguments.description: When you specify DBMS=XLS or DBMS=XLSX for an Excel file, you can read and write to Excel workbooks under Linux directly without having to access the SAS PC Files Server. This example demonstrates use of DBMS=XLSX specifying a range of cells.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: overwrites an existing SAS data set.

arguments.name: SAS
arguments.description: specifies SAS data set options.

arguments.name: file-format-specific-statements
arguments.description: See for the supported syntax for your data source.

arguments.name: SERVERAUTHDOMAIN=
arguments.description: Allows connection to a server by specifying the name of an authentication domain metadata object.

statements.name: DATAROW
statements.description: Starts reading data from the specified row number in the delimited text file.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the row number in the input file for the IMPORT procedure to start reading data.

statements.name: DBENCODING
statements.description: Indicates the encoding character set to use for the JMP file.

arguments.name: 12-char
arguments.description: indicates the encoding to use with JMP files. Encoding maps each character in a character set to a unique numeric representation, which results in a table of code points. A single character can have different numeric representations in different encodings. This value can be up to 12 characters long.

statements.name: DELIMITER
statements.description: Specifies the delimiter that separates columns of data in the input file.

arguments.name: char
arguments.description: specifies the delimiter that separates columns of data in the input file. You can specify the delimiter as a single character or as a hexadecimal value. For example, if columns of data are separated by an ampersand, specify DELIMITER='&'.

arguments.name: ''x
arguments.description: specifies the delimiter that separates columns of data in the input file. You can specify the delimiter as a single character or as a hexadecimal value. For example, if columns of data are separated by an ampersand, specify DELIMITER='&'.

statements.name: FMTLIB
statements.description: Saves value labels to the specified SAS format catalog.

arguments.name: libref.format-catalog
arguments.description: specifies the format catalog where the value labels are saved.

statements.name: GETNAMES
statements.description: Specifies whether the IMPORT procedure generates SAS variable names from the data values in the first row in the input file.

statements.name: GETSHEETNAMES
statements.description: Returns the worksheet names within an Excel file as a SAS data set.

statements.name: GUESSINGROWS
statements.description: Specifies the number of rows of the file to scan to determine the appropriate data type and length for the variables.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: indicates the number of rows the IMPORT procedure scans in the input file to determine the appropriate data type and length of variables. The range is 1 to 2147483647 (or MAX). The scan data process scans from row 1 to the number that is specified by the GUESSINGROWS option.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: can be specified instead of 2147483647. Specifying the maximum value could adversely affect performance.

statements.name: META
statements.description: Saves JMP metadata information to the specified SAS data set. (Deprecated)

arguments.name: libref.member-data-set
arguments.description: specifies the SAS data set that contains the metadata information is to be written.

statements.name: VARNAMEROW
statements.description: Specifies a row from the delimited text file that contains the variable names.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the row number in the input delimited file that contains the variable names.
